sentence: It would appear that prior concerns about rising interest rates have disappeared as quickly as those fears mounted.
As with last week, equities closed higher on Friday, sending the S&P 500 — closing at 2,747.30 — back above its 50-day moving average, which is an important psychological benchmark for traders.
Lead by a 1% gain in Amazon (AMZN), which made a new all-week high of $1,503.49, the Nasdaq ended the holiday-shortened trading week higher by 1.35%.

Combined with the meeting minutes released from Federal Reserve, suggesting that interest rates won’t be raised as aggressively as feared, solid earnings and upbeat guidance from the likes of Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), which sent HPE shares soaring more than 10%, were the main drivers of higher equity prices.
This coming week should bring more of the same.
Here are a few stocks to keep an eye on.
Wall Street expects a per-share loss of 1 cent on revenue of $589.1 million, compared to the year-ago quarter of a loss of 56 cents per share on $573.77 million in revenue.

What to Watch: The market for wearable devices is expected to climb over the next couple of years, according to market research firm IDC, which forecasts the global wearable market to grow at a CAGR of 18.4% between 2017 and 2021.
While that rate of growth may help the company improve its revenue total, can Fitbit capture enough market share from the likes of Apple (AAPL) and Garmin (GRMN) to make its stock attractive?
The stock has lost 12% over the past year, driven by pricing headwinds in both its high- and low-end products.

What to Watch: New product launches for both network and cloud-based applications has strengthened Palo Alto’s revenue which grew in Q1 27% year over year.
And that trend is expected to propel the stock higher in 2018, despite intense competition from the likes of Check Point (CHKP), Cisco (CSCO) and Fortinet (FTNT) in the firewall security market.
Last week Susquehanna analyst Anne Meisner upgraded PANW stock from Neutral to Positive and raised her price target from $150 to $195, calling for 20% premium from current levels.
Wall Street expects EPS of $14.11 on revenue of $2.7 billion, compared to the year-ago quarter of EPS of $14.21 per share on $2.35 billion in revenue.
What to Watch: What’s in a name?
Well, a lot, according to Booking Holdings management, which adopted the name to embrace what it believes to be its core business.
On Tuesday, analysts — many of whom have applauded the change — will look to see if the company can extend its string of earnings beats to five.

While weaker average daily rates for accommodations (ADR) and increasing advertising spend may pressure the bottom line, the long-term sentiment on the company, as evidenced by its consensus Buy rating, remains favorable.

What to Watch: The cloud computing giant is poised to report not only a top- and bottom-line beat, but also stellar guidance.
